title: A Tale of Two Structures: Do Large Language Models Capture the Fractal Complexity of Language?
author: Ibrahim Alabdulmohsin (Google DeepMind, Zurich, Switzerland), Andreas Steiner (Google DeepMind, Zurich, Switzerland), ...
relevance_why: The analysis of language models' fractal structure is directly applicable to audio-language processing tasks, helping understand how generative models can better mimic human language patterns in audio context.
background: Investigating whether large language models replicate the complex fractal patterns found in human languages, focusing on self-similarity and long-range dependence.
contribution: This paper introduces the exploration of fractal parameters (Holder and Hurst exponents) to evaluate the ability of language models to reflect the complexity of natural language, providing new insights into model performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods primarily rely on log-perplexity as a performance metric, which might not capture higher-order statistical properties.
technical_comparison.novelty: This study utilizes fractal parameters to offer a deeper understanding of language model outputs beyond first-order statistics.

key_innovation: The unique application of fractal analysis to assess large language models contrasts their outputs with natural language complexity, revealing systemic biases in generated texts.
real_world_impact: The findings can inform improvements in generative models, contributing to creating more realistic and context-aware audio outputs for applications like speech synthesis and music generation.
limitations: The metrics used may not provide reliable conclusions about individual documents or short texts, limiting detection capabilities.

new_terms.Holder exponent: **Holder exponent** characterizes self-similarity in time series data, where lower values indicate a more significant self-similar structure.
new_terms.Hurst exponent: **Hurst exponent** measures long-range dependence in a time series, where values greater than 0.5 suggest a persistent trend.

open_sourcing: The dataset, comprising over 240,000 articles generated by various language models, is publicly available.
